This is a 62-year-old Hispanic male – let's call him Martin.


Martin is trying to sleep. But he's rolling around in bed, sleepless.

We don't tell stories about people like Martin. He doesn't have a job. He doesn't have a wife or partner, nor does he have children in his home. He's just a regular guy in his 60s who doesn't interact with that many people. But he recorded everything he did for one day in 2021.¹ From that data, we know he may not have friends, family, or even acquaintances – and we know he's pretty unhappy. These are red flags. Humans evolved to survive in groups, whether that's gathering food or fighting off predators. Without those protective bonds, our bodies sound the alarm. "When we feel lonely, we’re unhappy and long to escape this emotional pain," writes former US surgeon general Vivek Murthy in his 2020 book, Together. When we're lonely, we feel more anxious, more fearful, and more stressed. Because thousands of years of evolution made us believe that when we're isolated, we're in danger.
¹ He did it for the American Time Use Survey, which has tracked how Americans spend their time since 2003.
Martin got out of bed and is watching TV.

In this story, we'll go through 24 hours of people's lives, including Martin.¹ By the end, we'll see a worrisome trend – hiding in plain sight. It looks like Martin is fine for now. Let's take a look at some more people.
¹ We'll limit it to Saturdays and Sundays, when people have more time to socialize.

The average human can put a name to about 1,500 people, and we personally know about 500.¹ But most of those people won't help us in times of need, nor will they make us feel less isolated. The people who will help are our friends – and psychologist Robin Dunbar argues that we have an average of 150 people who we try to contact at least once a year.² These are basically people you'd want to invite to your wedding. Within that group, he found we have about 15 friends we contact each month and one to two people with whom we share an intimate relationship – often a partner, and sometimes a "best friend forever." >> DUNBAR CHART – BUT COLOR WITH SAME THING WE'LL USE BELOW
¹ According to facial recognition research by Rob Jenkins at the University of York
² Dunbar argues that an animal's brain size limits the number of stable relationships we can maintain, and for humans it is 150. Recent studies argue that there is no empirical evidence for this limit. We won't solve this argument in a footnote, so just imagine this group as people you'd want to invite to your wedding.
So let's color code our friends and family with purple and everyone else with gray.

Everyone needs a different amount of social interaction. But according to the American Time Use Survey, the average American spends about 6 hours with friends or family each day. So let's track how many of these people interact with their friends or family for at least 6 hours a day. For the time spent with everyone else – acquaintances, coworkers, etc. – I'll give partial credit.¹ >> LEGEND ON SOCIAL INTERACTION
¹ A 2022 study of people's behavior during the Covid-19 pandemic found that people feel about 40% as psychologically close to acquaintances as they to do friends. This is admittedly not the most robust way to give partial credit for non-friends and family, but I couldn't find anything better.
Martin came home from the grocery store and he's preparing lunch.
After lunch, he decided to watch TV again. He's been around other people today, like at the grocery store. But he hasn't done anything with other people.

Lonely people exhibit different behavior than everyone else. They report feeling more shy, more anxious, more negative, and more angry. They are less optimistic and have lower self esteem. But neuroscientist John Cacioppo has found that everyone is susceptible to the negative effects of loneliness. In a 2006 study, he and his colleagues hypnotized a bunch of college students to feel lonely. After confirming the hypnotism worked, they asked the students how they felt. Cacioppo found that the hypnotized lonely students reported feeling just as bad as people who were actually lonely. "We had demonstrated yet again that lonely individuals are not a breed apart," Cacioppo wrote in his book, Loneliness. "Any of us can succumb to loneliness, and along with it, all the other characteristics that travel as its entourage."

When I analyzed how much time Americans spend with other people, I found some alarming trends. The amount of time we spend with family has drastically decreased across every age group: >> FAMILY CHART And the amount of time we spend with friends has plummeted: >> FRIENDS CHART Meanwhile, the amount of time we spend alone has gone up across every age group: >> AGE GROUP CHART Being alone isn't necessarily the same as being lonely. But according to a meta-analysis of studies, more people have reported feeling lonely every year since 1976. Then the pandemic came along. It supercharged our loneliness.
As you can see, most people have barely had an hour of social interaction on this day – and this is the weekend!

Every so often, the American Time Use Survey asks people a question that gets at how well someone is doing. The last time it was asked was 2021, which is the year we're looking at. The question goes something like this:
Imagine a ladder. The top of the ladder is your best possible life. The bottom is your worst possible life. Which step of the ladder do you feel you personally stand at the present time?
This is called the Cantril ladder, and in the US most people answer fairly positively – on average, people say they are a 7 out of 10. Pause for a second and ask yourself where you are on this ladder: >> CHART: CANTRIL LADDER

Martin is still watching TV.


When Martin was asked where he is on the Cantril ladder, he said zero – living his worst possible life.


He'll keep watching TV until around 8:30pm and then go to sleep.
Let's look at where everyone else is on the Cantril ladder. I'll sort them so we can see it better.

The day is almost over, and we can clearly see a trend: People lower on the ladder are far more likely to have gone a full day being mostly isolated.


If we look at everyone who answered this question in 2021, we can see that TKTKTKT.


>> CANTRIL CHART

Loneliness robs you of your best self. Research has shown that isolated people are less generous with donations, less likely to persevere in the face of adversity, more likely to procrastinate, and more likely to administer harsher punishments.¹ Lonely people get lower quality sleep. Ultimately, lonely people are 50% more likely to die prematurely than people with strong social connections – the equivalent of having six alcoholic drinks a day or smoking 15 cigarettes a day.
¹ From Cacioppo's book, Loneliness

We ostracize lonely people. After all, if other people aren't helping them fight predators, there must be a reason. So when we experience loneliness, we hide it. Not only that, but we become even more wary of social interactions – which is the very thing we need. It feels like we're self-sabotaging ourselves. It feels like our fault. "Over time," Murthy writes, "this vicious cycle may convince us we don’t matter to anyone and that we’re unworthy of love."

Experts have said we are experiencing an "epidemic of loneliness."


But we often treat it like an individual problem – as if it's our own damn fault that we don't have people around us.


Sure, you could blame more and more people for being isolated. But what if we've created a world that tells people they aren't worthy of love?

It's easy to keep our eyes on the people who aren't lonely. Their lives are more active. Their squares are more lively. They are the kind of people journalists, like myself, tend to write about. But when I follow individual people in this data, they remind me of people in my life – grandparents, friends, coworkers – and sometimes, me. And I found myself wanting to tell them: Hey, I see you.
